_header: He that will his soul leche / Listeneth to me and I woll…
Note: For other MSS see 3212; for prose versions cf. Canterbury Cath. Z.8.33, olim Ingilby, f. 1; Aberystwyth, National Library of Wales Brogyntyn ii.1 [olim Porkington 10], f. 132

BLAdd37787.First Lines:
…þan I haue told here by foreOr telle schuld with alle
                    myght…
BLAdd37787.Last Lines:
…Graunt vs parte of þis pardoneAnd þer to
                    his…
BLAdd37787.Note:
The text is incomplete due to damage to the manuscript. Only the final
                    seven lines of the text remain, and part of the last line is
                    missing.
BLAdd37787.Editions:
Baugh,  Nita Scudder. 
             A Worcestershire Miscellany, compiled by John
                    Northwood, c. 1400, edited from British Museum MS. Add.
                37,787.
         Philadelphia, 1956: 106.

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
He þat wyll hys sowle lecheLysteneth to me & y woll
                    ȝou teche…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines:
…And six þowsand ȝere he ȝaf to pardonTo all
                    þo þat þyder wyll come
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
Incypyt þe stacyonys of Rome (f. 83rb, by scribe, written
                    in upper margin); S of Rome (as RT on verso leaves thereafter); Explicit þe
                    staciones of Rome (f. 86va, by scribe below last line); The stations
                    of Rome (f. 1, sixteenth-century list of contents)
BlCottCalAII.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 113-44; rev. ed. 143-73 (lines 554-914).

BLCottVesDIX.First Lines: …ffor no man can that pardone sayPasse we now forthe in owter wey…
BLCottVesDIX.Last Lines: …A pater noster and an aueAmen for charyte amen amen amen for charyte
BLCottVesDIX.Note: Begins imperfectly (lacking lines 1-100); rubric after end reads ‘Amen quod Bertran watoun’, followed by a monogram.

Lam306.First Lines:
Who so wolle be his soulles lechelyst ynnythe to me I wyll yowe
                    teche…
Lam306.Last Lines:
…Graunt vs partie of this pardoneAnd there withe gyve us his
                    benysone
Lam306.Attributed Title:
The stacyons of Rome (f. 152v); Explicit þe stacions of
                    Roome (f. 165)
Lam306.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 113-44; rev. ed. 143-73 (lines 554-914).

PROSC69565.Note: Lines 1-667; after line 19, verse copied as prose.
PROSC69565.Editions:
Scattergood,  V. John. 
             “An Inedited Manuscript of The Stacions of Rome.” 
             English Philological Studies
         11 (1968): 51-4: 51 (unique passages only).

ChicagoAdd12.First Lines:
He þat wil his soule lecheList to me I wil him
                    [te]chPardoun his soule boteAt grete rome þere is þe
                    rote…
ChicagoAdd12.Last Lines:
…graunt vs parte of þis pardounAnd þer to his holy
                    benisoune

BodWoodEmpt25.First Lines:
Who so wyll be his soules lecheLysten to me j wyll hym
                    teche…
BodWoodEmpt25.Last Lines:
…Heþen it was & cristen nou[t]Tyll peter & poul
                    hit hadde bout
BodWoodEmpt25.Note:
12 lines. See Keiser (2003)
XKeiser,  George R. 
             “Verse Introductions to Middle English Medical Treatises.” 
             English Studies
         84 (2003): 301-17, 314-15 for the argument
                    reassigning this text from 6710
                    to this entry.
